sn5.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho sīsupacālā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā …pe…
sn5.8:1.2.eng: Then the nun Sīsupacālā robed up in the morning …

sn5.8:1.3.eng: and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

sn5.8:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena sīsupacālā bhikkhunī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sīsupacālaṃ bhikkhuniṃ etadavoca:
sn5.8:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to Sīsupacālā and said to her,

sn5.8:1.5.eng: “Nun, whose creed do you approve of?”
sn5.8:1.5.comm: Pāsaṇḍa (“creed”) is unique in the Suttas, but we find it also at Bu Pc 32:8.1.

sn5.8:2.1.eng: “In whose name did you shave your head?

sn5.8:2.3.eng: but you don’t approve any creed.

sn5.8:2.4.eng: Why do you wander as if lost?”

sn5.8:3.3.eng: But I don’t approve their teaching,

sn5.8:3.4.eng: for they’re no experts in the Dhamma.

sn5.8:4.1.eng: But there is one born in the Sakyan clan,

sn5.8:5.3.eng: He has attained the end of all deeds,

sn5.8:5.4.eng: freed with the ending of attachments.

sn5.8:5.5.eng: That Blessed One is my Teacher,

sn5.8:6.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ sīsupacālā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.8:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Sīsupacālā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn5.9:1.2.pli: Atha kho selā bhikkhunī pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā …pe…
sn5.9:1.2.eng: Then the nun Selā robed up in the morning …
sn5.9:1.2.comm: As noted, the verses of Selā at Thig 3.7 are attributed to Āḷavikā at SN 5.1. The verses here have no Pali parallels, and it is unclear whether this is the same person.

sn5.9:1.3.eng: and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

sn5.9:1.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā selāya bhikkhuniyā bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo …pe…
sn5.9:1.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Selā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps …

sn5.9:2.1.comm: “Puppet” is bimba; the similarity to English “bimbo” seems a coincidence.

sn5.9:3.2.pli: “ko nu khvāyaṃ manusso vā amanusso vā gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti?
sn5.9:3.2.eng: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”

sn5.9:3.4.pli: “māro kho ayaṃ pāpimā mama bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo samādhimhā cāvetukāmo gāthaṃ bhāsatī”ti.
sn5.9:3.4.eng: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from immersion!”

sn5.9:3.5.pli: Atha kho selā bhikkhunī “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi paccabhāsi:
sn5.9:3.5.eng: Then Selā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn5.9:4.1.comm: This contradicts eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.10, “for he is the maker”.

sn5.9:4.2.eng: nor is this gloom made by another.
sn5.9:4.2.comm: Neither of the two Chinese parallels at SA2 219 or SA 1203 contain any parallel to agha (“gloom”).

sn5.9:4.3.eng: It comes to be because of a cause,

sn5.9:4.4.eng: and ceases when the cause breaks up.

sn5.9:5.1.eng: It’s like a seed that’s sown
sn5.9:5.1.comm: Selā uses the imagery of agriculture to illustrate the organic, changing nature of an individual, who survives supported by multiple conditions.

sn5.9:5.3.eng: relying on both the soil’s nutrients

sn5.9:6.1.eng: In the same way the aggregates and elements

sn5.9:6.3.eng: come to be because of a cause,

sn5.9:6.4.eng: and cease when the cause breaks up.”

sn5.9:7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ selā bhikkhunī”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn5.9:7.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Selā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn6.1:1.1.comm: A similar account is told of Gotama Buddha at MN 26:19.2, MN 85:43.2, and Kd 1:5.2.2, and of Vipassī at DN 14:3.1.4.

sn6.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn6.1:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

sn6.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn6.1:1.3.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn6.1:1.4.pli: “adhigato kho myāyaṃ dhammo gambhīro duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo.
sn6.1:1.4.eng: “This principle I have discovered is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.

sn6.1:1.5.pli: Ālayarāmā kho panāyaṃ pajā ālayaratā ālayasammuditā.
sn6.1:1.5.eng: But people like clinging, they love it and enjoy it.

sn6.1:1.6.pli: Ālayarāmāya kho pana pajāya ālayaratāya ālayasammuditāya duddasaṃ idaṃ ṭhānaṃ yadidaṃ idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo.
sn6.1:1.6.eng: It’s hard for them to see this topic; that is, specific conditionality, dependent origination.
sn6.1:1.6.comm: “Specific conditionality” (idappaccayatā) refers to the fact that dependent origination traces the specific conditions for other specific things: this conditions that. It is not a general principle of universal conditionality (“everything is interconnected”). | Dependent origination (PAṭICCASAMUPPāDA) is treated in detail in SN 12.

sn6.1:1.7.pli: Idampi kho ṭhānaṃ duddasaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho nibbānaṃ.
sn6.1:1.7.eng: It’s also hard for them to see this topic; that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

sn6.1:1.8.pli: Ahañceva kho pana dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ; pare ca me na ājāneyyuṃ; so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
sn6.1:1.8.eng: And if I were to teach this principle, others might not understand me, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
sn6.1:1.8.comm: Up to this point, the Bodhisatta has been solely concerned with finding the answer to his quest, and only now does he think of sharing it with others. The idea that he had made an aspiration for Buddhahood in the long ago past out of a desire to help all sentient beings is not supported in early texts.

sn6.1:1.9.pli: Apissu bhagavantaṃ imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsu pubbe assutapubbā:
sn6.1:1.9.eng: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to the Buddha:
sn6.1:1.9.comm: “Not supernaturally inspired” (anacchariyā) rejects the Vedic “channeling” of scripture from the Divinity, while “not learned before in the past” (pubbe assutapubbā), echoing the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:5.1), rejects the oral tradition.

sn6.1:2.2.eng: enough with trying to explain it!

sn6.1:2.3.eng: Those mired in greed and hate

sn6.1:3.1.eng: It goes against the stream, subtle,

sn6.1:3.3.eng: Those besotted by greed cannot see,

sn6.1:3.4.eng: for they’re shrouded in a mass of darkness.”

sn6.1:4.1.pli: Itiha bhagavato paṭisañcikkhato appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāya.
sn6.1:4.1.eng: And as the Buddha reflected like this, his mind inclined to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.
sn6.1:4.1.comm: Had he followed this inclination he would have been a paccekabuddha, a Buddha “awakened for himself”.

sn6.1:5.1.pli: Atha kho brahmuno sahampatissa bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya etadahosi:
sn6.1:5.1.eng: Then, knowing the Buddha’s train of thought, it occurred to the divinity Sahampati,
sn6.1:5.1.comm: While Sahampati features prominently in the suttas, no deity of that name is found in early Brahmanical texts. He seems, however, to be the Buddhist version of Brahmā Svayambhū, the “Self-born Divinity”, to whom Yājñavalkya traces the authority of his teaching lineage (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.6.3, 4.5.3, 6.5.4). Yājñavalkya identifies this “self-born” with the sun (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.9.3.16; see also Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.6.6) and with Prajāpati (13.5.3.1). Explaining the origin of the soma rite of the “All-Sacrifice”, he says that Brahmā Svayambhū, while performing fervent austerities, decided to offer his self to all creatures and all creatures to his self, thus establishing lordship (adhipatya) over all creatures (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.7.1.1). The root pati (“lord”) here establishes a linguistic link with sahampati. Further, in the earliest use of svayambhū at Rig Veda 10.83.4, the “self-born” deity Manyu “prevails” (sahuriḥ sahāvān) in battle. Thus we can identify Sahampati, the “Lord Who Prevails”, with the highest divinity recognized by Yājñavalkya, who originated as victor in battle, whose physical manifestation is the sun, whose spiritual function is to imbue all creatures with divinity, and who serves as the ultimate source of authority. Meanwhile, the epithet sayambhū was taken for the Buddha (Kd 11:35.1.37).

sn6.1:5.2.pli: “nassati vata bho loko, vinassati vata bho loko, yatra hi nāma tathāgatassa arahato sammāsambuddhassa appossukkatāya cittaṃ namati, no dhammadesanāyā”ti.
sn6.1:5.2.eng: “Oh lord! The world will be lost, the world will perish! For the mind of the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, inclines to remaining passive, not to teaching the Dhamma.”
sn6.1:5.2.comm: Having surpassed the greatest of the Brahmanical contemplatives, the Buddha’s achievement is recognized by the chief Brahmanical divinity. | The Pali vata bho works much like the English exclamation “oh lord” as an appeal to authority (bho), often in a purely rhetorical sense.

sn6.1:5.3.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito bhagavato purato pāturahosi.
sn6.1:5.3.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.

sn6.1:5.4.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalaṃ pathaviyaṃ nihantvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.1:5.4.eng: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn6.1:5.5.pli: “desetu, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṃ, desetu sugato dhammaṃ.
sn6.1:5.5.eng: “Sir, let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma! Let the Holy One teach the Dhamma!

sn6.1:5.6.pli: Santi sattā apparajakkhajātikā, assavanatā dhammassa parihāyanti.
sn6.1:5.6.eng: There are beings with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.

sn6.1:5.7.eng: There will be those who understand the teaching!”
sn6.1:5.7.comm: Sahampati is the one who recognizes the potential in all beings, since it was he who imbued them with divinity. He did this to ensure dominance, but now his motive has transformed into compassion.

sn6.1:5.8.pli: Idamavoca brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvā athāparaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.1:5.8.eng: This is what the divinity Sahampati said. Then he went on to say:

sn6.1:6.1.eng: “Among the Magadhans there appeared in the past

sn6.1:6.2.eng: an impure teaching thought up by the stained.
sn6.1:6.2.comm: The “impure teaching” was, according to the commentary, that of the six ascetic teachers, who are regularly associated with Magadha (eg. SN 2.30, Snp 3.6, DN 2). Less likely it refers to Brahmanical teachers like Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka Rāmaputta, who are more closely associated with Kosala and whose system is regarded as passed down rather than “thought up”.

sn6.1:6.3.eng: Fling open the door to freedom from death!
sn6.1:6.3.comm: “Freedom from death” (amata, Sanskrit amṛta) is yet another Brahmanical term transformed by the Buddha. Its Vedic meaning was “immortality”, and hence the “ambrosia” of soma through which immortality was gained. For the Buddha, as seen in the “noble quest” itself, it was the freedom from the cycles of birth, aging, and death.

sn6.1:6.4.eng: Let them hear the teaching <j>the immaculate one discovered.

sn6.1:7.1.eng: Standing high on a rocky mountain,

sn6.1:7.2.eng: you can see the people all around.

sn6.1:7.3.eng: In just the same way, All-seer, so intelligent,

sn6.1:7.4.eng: having ascended the Temple of Truth,

sn6.1:7.5.eng: rid of sorrow, look upon the people

sn6.1:7.6.eng: swamped with sorrow,  <j>oppressed by rebirth and old age.

sn6.1:8.1.eng: Rise, hero! Victor in battle, caravan leader,
sn6.1:8.1.comm: Here we see a verbal echo of Sahampati’s martial origins.

sn6.1:8.2.eng: wander the world cleared of debt.
sn6.1:8.2.comm: A “caravan leader” (satthavāha) guides their flock through treacherous deserts and wastelands, as illustrated at DN 23:23.3. | Anaṇa (“debtless”) is a technical term in the Vedic system. According to Manu 6.35–7, a renunciate must first pay off three debts: study of Vedas, begetting a son, and offering of sacrifices. One who goes forth with these debts unpaid is headed for a downfall. The Buddha has indeed paid off all these debts: he studied the Vedas under his former teachers (MN 26:15.6); he has a son Rāhula; and his path is regarded as the highest form of sacrifice (DN 5:24.1). But in Buddhism the concept is reinterpreted as meaning one has let go of all defilements, becoming a “perfected”, literally “worthy” one, after which one can eat almsfood free of debt (MN 124:38.1, SN 16.11:13.2).

sn6.1:8.3.eng: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!

sn6.1:8.4.eng: There will be those who understand!”

sn6.1:9.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā brahmuno ca ajjhesanaṃ viditvā sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesi.
sn6.1:9.1.eng: Then the Buddha, understanding the Divinity’s invitation, surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha, out of his compassion for sentient beings.

sn6.1:9.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
sn6.1:9.2.eng: And the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.
sn6.1:9.2.comm: Here we see the sense of indriya as “spiritual potential”. Originally it was the state of excited energy produced by soma that allowed Indra to manifest his full power and overcome his foes. It implicitly links back to the five spiritual qualities that the Buddha attributed to his teachers, which he later formalized as “faculties”. Here as there, the idea creates a connection between beings, a recognition of shared qualities that, when properly nurtured, can mature into awakening. | For the “fault to do with the next world” see AN 2.1.

sn6.1:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma uppaliniyaṃ vā paduminiyaṃ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṃ vā appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni anto nimuggaposīni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni samodakaṃ ṭhitāni, appekaccāni uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṃvaḍḍhāni udakā accuggamma ṭhitāni anupalittāni udakena;
sn6.1:9.3.eng: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. Some of them sprout and grow in the water reaching the water’s surface. And some of them sprout and grow in the water but rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to them.

sn6.1:9.4.pli: evameva bhagavā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokento addasa satte apparajakkhe mahārajakkhe tikkhindriye mudindriye svākāre dvākāre suviññāpaye duviññāpaye, appekacce paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante, appekacce na paralokavajjabhayadassāvine viharante.
sn6.1:9.4.eng: In the same way, the Buddha saw sentient beings with little dust in their eyes, and some with much dust in their eyes; with keen faculties and with weak faculties, with good qualities and with bad qualities, easy to teach and hard to teach. And some of them lived seeing the danger in the fault to do with the next world, while others did not.

sn6.1:9.5.eng: When he had seen this he replied in verse to the divinity Sahampati:

sn6.1:10.1.eng: “Flung open are the doors to freedom from death!

sn6.1:10.2.eng: Let those with ears to hear commit to faith.
sn6.1:10.2.comm: Pamuñcantu saddhaṁ has long troubled translators, as the basic sense of pamuñcantu is “release”. The problem is a long-standing one, for Sanskrit variants include pramodantu (“celebrate”) or praṇudantu kāṅkṣāḥ (“dispel doubts”). I think it is a poetic variant of adhimuñcantu, to “decide” or “commit” to faith; it is extremely common in Pali to use a synonymous verb to reinforce the sense of the noun. In Snp 5.19, muttasaddho, pamuñcassu saddhaṁ, and adhimuttacittaṁ are all used in this sense.

sn6.1:10.3.eng: Thinking it would be troublesome, Divinity, <j>I did not teach

sn6.1:10.4.eng: the sophisticated, sublime Dhamma among mankind.”

sn6.1:11.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati “katāvakāso khomhi bhagavatā dhammadesanāyā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn6.1:11.1.eng: Then the divinity Sahampati, knowing that his request for the Buddha to teach the Dhamma had been granted, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

sn6.10:1.1.comm: A difficult problem of this text is the meaning of the numbers of the duration of hell. See the extended version at Snp 3.10 for full discussion; it has an extra passage which is essential  for decoding.

sn6.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.2.eng: Then the mendicant Kokālika went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn6.10:1.3.pli: “pāpicchā, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānā pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gatā”ti.
sn6.10:1.3.eng: “Sir, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”

sn6.10:1.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.4.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

sn6.10:1.5.pli: “mā hevaṃ, kokālika, avaca; mā hevaṃ, kokālika, avaca.
sn6.10:1.5.eng: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!

sn6.10:1.6.pli: Pasādehi, kokālika, sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ. Pesalā sāriputtamoggallānā”ti.
sn6.10:1.6.eng: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, they’re good monks.”

sn6.10:1.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.7.eng: For a second time Kokālika said to the Buddha,

sn6.10:1.8.pli: “kiñcāpi me, bhante, bhagavā saddhāyiko paccayiko; atha kho pāpicchāva bhante, sāriputtamoggallānā pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gatā”ti.
sn6.10:1.8.eng: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”

sn6.10:1.9.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.9.eng: For a second time, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

sn6.10:1.10.pli: “mā hevaṃ, kokālika, avaca; mā hevaṃ, kokālika, avaca.
sn6.10:1.10.eng: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!

sn6.10:1.11.pli: Pasādehi, kokālika, sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ. Pesalā sāriputtamoggallānā”ti.
sn6.10:1.11.eng: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, they’re good monks.”

sn6.10:1.12.pli: Tatiyampi kho kokāliko bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.12.eng: For a third time Kokālika said to the Buddha,

sn6.10:1.13.eng: “Despite my faith and trust in the Buddha, Sāriputta and Moggallāna have corrupt wishes. They’ve fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.”

sn6.10:1.14.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā kokālikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:1.14.eng: For a third time, the Buddha said to Kokālika,

sn6.10:1.15.eng: “Don’t say that, Kokālika! Don’t say that, Kokālika!

sn6.10:1.16.eng: Have confidence in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, they’re good monks.”

sn6.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn6.10:2.1.eng: Then Kokālika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn6.10:2.2.pli: Acirapakkantassa ca kokālikassa bhikkhuno sāsapamattīhi pīḷakāhi sabbo kāyo phuṭo ahosi.
sn6.10:2.2.eng: Not long after he left his body erupted with boils the size of mustard seeds.

sn6.10:2.3.pli: Sāsapamattiyo hutvā muggamattiyo ahesuṃ, muggamattiyo hutvā kalāyamattiyo ahesuṃ, kalāyamattiyo hutvā kolaṭṭhimattiyo ahesuṃ, kolaṭṭhimattiyo hutvā kolamattiyo ahesuṃ, kolamattiyo hutvā āmalakamattiyo ahesuṃ, āmalakamattiyo hutvā beluvasalāṭukamattiyo ahesuṃ, beluvasalāṭukamattiyo hutvā billamattiyo ahesuṃ, billamattiyo hutvā pabhijjiṃsu. Pubbañca lohitañca pagghariṃsu.
sn6.10:2.3.eng: The boils grew to the size of mung beans, then chickpeas, then jujube seeds, then jujubes, then myrobalans, then unripe wood-apples, then ripe wood-apples. Finally they burst open, and pus and blood oozed out.

sn6.10:2.4.pli: Atha kho kokāliko bhikkhu teneva ābādhena kālamakāsi.
sn6.10:2.4.eng: Then the mendicant Kokālika died of that illness.

sn6.10:2.5.pli: Kālaṅkato ca kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapajji sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā.
sn6.10:2.5.eng: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

sn6.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho brahmā sahampati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:3.1.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious divinity Sahampati, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

sn6.10:3.2.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Kokālika has passed away.

sn6.10:3.3.pli: Kālaṅkato ca, bhante, kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā”ti.
sn6.10:3.3.eng: He was reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

sn6.10:3.4.eng: That’s what the divinity Sahampati said.

sn6.10:3.5.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn6.10:3.5.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right side, before vanishing right there.

sn6.10:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn6.10:4.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

sn6.10:4.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ brahmā sahampati abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati maṃ etadavoca:

sn6.10:4.4.pli: Kālaṅkato ca, bhante, kokāliko bhikkhu padumaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā’ti.

sn6.10:4.5.pli: Idamavoca, bhikkhave, brahmā sahampati, idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.

sn6.10:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn6.10:5.1.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

sn6.10:5.2.pli: “kīvadīghaṃ nu kho, bhante, padume niraye āyuppamāṇan”ti?
sn6.10:5.2.eng: “Sir, how long is the lifespan in the Pink Lotus hell?”

sn6.10:5.5.pli: ‘ettakāni vassāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasatāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasahassāni iti vā, ettakāni vassasatasahassāni iti vā’”ti.
sn6.10:5.5.eng: how many years, how many hundreds or thousands or hundreds of thousands of years it lasts.”

sn6.10:5.6.eng: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”

sn6.10:6.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho. Tato puriso vassasatassa vassasatassa accayena ekamekaṃ tilaṃ uddhareyya;
sn6.10:6.1.eng: “Suppose there was a Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed. And at the end of every hundred years someone would remove a single seed from it.
sn6.10:6.1.comm: Duration by the “Kosalan load” comes to either 150 billion years (using the Arthaśāstra khāri) or 25 billion years (using the Pali khāri). Neither of these results agrees with the other calculations in this Sutta. The correspondence is not in the result but the simple numbers: twenty packs each hundred years correspond to the twenty times ten of the hells.

sn6.10:6.2.pli: khippataraṃ kho so, bhikkhu, vīsatikhāriko kosalako tilavāho iminā upakkamena parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya, na tveva eko abbudo nirayo.
sn6.10:6.2.eng: By this means the Kosalan load of twenty packs of sesame seed would run out faster than a single lifetime in the Abbuda hell.
sn6.10:6.2.comm: Ten hells are listed here, the names of which do not correspond with the 21 or 28 listed in Purāṇas, nor with the seven Jain hells, nor with the hells of MN 130. The commentary offers three explanations for the obscure names of these hells: they are numbers reflecting the duration spent in Avīci; or they are the cries uttered by those suffering there; or they are simply the cold hells. | For other meanings of abbuda, see SN 10.1:3.2, SN 1.77:1.4.

sn6.10:6.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati abbudā nirayā, evameko nirabbudanirayo.
sn6.10:6.3.eng: Now, twenty lifetimes in the Abbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Nirabbuda hell.
sn6.10:6.3.comm: The Sanskrit nyarbuda (or nirbuda) is said, rather, to be ten times the arbuda. The expansion in a series of twenty is required to reach the final number, a multiple of 512.

sn6.10:6.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati nirabbudā nirayā, evameko ababo nirayo.
sn6.10:6.4.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Nirabbuda hell equal one lifetime in the Ababa hell.

sn6.10:6.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ababā nirayā, evameko aṭaṭo nirayo.
sn6.10:6.5.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Ababa hell equal one lifetime in the Aṭaṭa hell.

sn6.10:6.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati aṭaṭā nirayā, evameko ahaho nirayo.
sn6.10:6.6.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Aṭaṭa hell equal one lifetime in the Ahaha hell.

sn6.10:6.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati ahahā nirayā, evameko kumudo nirayo.
sn6.10:6.7.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Ahaha hell equal one lifetime in the Yellow Lotus hell.

sn6.10:6.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati kumudā nirayā, evameko sogandhiko nirayo.
sn6.10:6.8.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Yellow Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Fragrant Water Lily hell.

sn6.10:6.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati sogandhikā nirayā, evameko uppalanirayo.
sn6.10:6.9.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Fragrant Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the Blue Water Lily hell.
sn6.10:6.9.comm: The “Fragrant Water Lily” (sogandhika) is variously identified as blue or white.

sn6.10:6.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati uppalā nirayā, evameko puṇḍariko nirayo.
sn6.10:6.10.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the Blue Water Lily hell equal one lifetime in the White Lotus hell.

sn6.10:6.11.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhu, vīsati puṇḍarikā nirayā, evameko padumo nirayo.
sn6.10:6.11.eng: Twenty lifetimes in the White Lotus hell equal one lifetime in the Pink Lotus hell.
sn6.10:6.11.comm: By this calculation, the Pink Lotus lasts for 10⁷ ×  20⁹ = 5.12 × 10¹⁸ years.

sn6.10:6.12.pli: Padume pana, bhikkhu, niraye kokāliko bhikkhu upapanno sāriputtamoggallānesu cittaṃ āghātetvā”ti.
sn6.10:6.12.eng: The mendicant Kokālika has been reborn in the Pink Lotus hell because of his resentment for Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”

sn6.10:6.13.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn6.10:6.14.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn6.10:6.14.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn6.10:7.2.eng: with an axe in his mouth.

sn6.10:7.3.eng: A fool cuts themselves with it

sn6.10:8.1.eng: When you praise someone worthy of criticism,

sn6.10:8.2.eng: or criticize someone worthy of praise,

sn6.10:8.3.eng: you choose a losing hand with your own mouth:

sn6.10:8.4.eng: you’ll never find happiness that way.

sn6.10:9.1.eng: A losing hand at dice is a trivial thing,

sn6.10:9.2.eng: if all you lose is your money

sn6.10:9.3.eng: and all you own, even yourself.

sn6.10:9.5.eng: is to hate the holy ones.

sn6.10:10.1.eng: For a hundred thousand times a hundred million,

sn6.10:10.2.eng: times five hundred and thirty-six times <j>a thousand times ten million years
sn6.10:10.2.comm: Here, take an abbuda as 10 million and a nirabbuda as 100 million, and distribute the terms of the first line to the second, for a duration of 5.36 × 10²⁵ years. This is an amplified version of the same number as previous: triple twelve to thirty-six, and multiply by ten million.

sn6.10:10.3.eng: a slanderer of noble ones goes to hell,

sn6.10:10.4.eng: having aimed bad words and thoughts at them.”

sn6.10:11.2.pli: Bako ca brahmā aparā ca diṭṭhi;

sn6.10:11.4.pli: Turū ca brahmā aparo ca kokālikoti.
